title: Cybersecurity Comprehensive Exam
description: Updated 150-question objective test aligned with 2025-2026 FBLA National Standards.

questions.text: Which element of the CIA triad is compromised when an attacker performs a successful Ransomware encryption on a company database?
options: Confidentiality of the data
Availability of the services
Authenticity of the sender
Non-repudiation of the user

questions.text: What is the primary difference between a 'Security Policy' and a 'Security Procedure' in an organizational context?
options: Policies provide high-level goals while procedures provide step-by-step instructions
Policies are mandatory requirements while procedures are always optional guidelines
Policies are technical configurations while procedures are legal compliance documents
Policies focus on hardware settings while procedures focus on employee behavior

questions.text: The principle of 'Least Privilege' is best demonstrated by which of the following actions?
options: Giving all managers administrative access to simplify network troubleshooting tasks
Allowing users to install any software necessary for their daily productivity needs
Providing users only the access levels required to perform their specific job duties
Granting guest users access to internal files to facilitate easier collaboration

questions.text: Which of the following is considered an Administrative Control rather than a Technical or Physical control?
options: Implementing an automated intrusion prevention system on the main network
Conducting annual security awareness training for all department employees
Installing biometric scanners on the entrance to the server room facility
Configuring complex firewall rules to block unauthorized port 80 traffic

questions.text: In risk management, choosing to purchase an insurance policy to cover potential cyber losses is an example of:
options: Risk Avoidance strategy
Risk Acceptance strategy
Risk Mitigation strategy
Risk Transference strategy

questions.text: Which term describes the process of proving that a specific user actually performed a specific action on a computer system?
options: Authorization of user
Non-repudiation of user
Identification of user
Authentication of user

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of an 'Acceptable Use Policy' (AUP) in a business or school environment?
options: To define the technical specifications for high-speed network hardware
To outline the permitted and prohibited activities for all network users
To list the serial numbers of all company-owned mobile and desktop devices
To provide the contact information for the external cybersecurity consultants

questions.text: An organization decides to stop using a specific software because it is too vulnerable to attacks. This is an example of:
options: Risk Mitigation
Risk Acceptance
Risk Transference
Risk Avoidance

questions.text: Which type of control is a security camera that records footage of an unauthorized entry after it has already occurred?
options: Preventive control
Detective control
Corrective control
Deterrent control

questions.text: The 'Integrity' component of the CIA triad is most concerned with which of the following scenarios?
options: Ensuring that unauthorized users cannot read private financial data
Ensuring that information is not modified by unauthorized individuals
Ensuring that systems are operational and accessible during business hours
Ensuring that all users have identical permissions across all platforms

questions.text: What is the primary function of a 'Certificate Authority' (CA) in a secure digital environment?
options: To block malicious traffic from entering the local area network
To verify and issue digital certificates to entities and users
To store backup copies of all encrypted files in a remote cloud
To monitor employee emails for violations of company policies

questions.text: Which concept refers to the probability of a threat source exploiting a vulnerability and the resulting impact?
options: Security Asset
Security Threat
Security Risk
Security Breach

questions.text: Multi-factor Authentication (MFA) typically requires two or more elements from which three categories?
options: What you know, what you have, and what you are
What you say, what you do, and what you see
Where you work, where you live, and where you go
Who you know, who you like, and who you trust

questions.text: A security guard standing at the gate is primarily providing which type of security control?
options: Technical Control
Physical Control
Logical Control
Virtual Control

questions.text: What is the definition of 'Security Governance' within a large-scale modern organization?
options: The software used to manage the passwords of all administrative accounts
The framework of rules and practices that direct security operations
The physical locks used to secure the servers in the main data center
The antivirus software installed on all mobile devices and workstations

questions.text: Which document is legally binding and specifies the uptime and performance expectations for a service provider?
options: Memorandum of Understanding
Interconnection Security Agreement
Service Level Agreement
Non-Disclosure Agreement

questions.text: What is the primary role of 'Asset Management' in a comprehensive cybersecurity program?
options: To track and secure all hardware and software within the network
To manage the retirement funds for the IT and security staff
To negotiate the pricing for new server hardware and software
To design the user interface for the company's public website

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'Technical Control' used to protect the confidentiality of sensitive data?
options: A written policy about data handling
An encrypted storage volume or drive
A background check for new employees
A warning sign on the server room door

questions.text: The term 'Due Diligence' in cybersecurity refers to which of the following organizational actions?
options: The act of investigating and understanding risks before making decisions
The act of installing the latest firewall firmware every single month
The act of firing employees who fail to use complex account passwords
The act of purchasing the most expensive security software on the market

questions.text: Which type of security control is designed to discourage potential attackers from attempting a security breach?
options: Detective control
Deterrent control
Corrective control
Compensating control

questions.text: What does the term 'Air Gapping' refer to in the context of high-security computer systems?
options: Connecting systems via a high-speed wireless mesh network
Physically isolating a computer or network from all others
Installing extra cooling fans to prevent server overheating
Using cloud-based storage to sync files across multiple sites

questions.text: Which standard is widely used globally to provide a framework for managing information security systems?
options: ISO/IEC 27001
IEEE 802.11ac
ANSI/TIA 568
RFC 1918

questions.text: A 'Single Point of Failure' is best described as which of the following in a system design?
options: A user who forgets their password more than three times in a week
A component that, if it fails, stops the entire system from working
A software bug that only affects one specific version of an application
A network cable that is slightly longer than the standard requirements

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary goal of 'Change Management' in a secure IT environment?
options: To ensure that all employees change their passwords every thirty days
To ensure that system modifications do not compromise security or stability
To ensure that every computer is replaced with a newer model every year
To ensure that the company switches to a new internet provider every month

questions.text: What is 'Shoulder Surfing' in the context of physical security and social engineering?
options: Looking over someone's shoulder to see their password or sensitive data
Using a wireless scanner to steal data from a laptop in a public place
Asking an employee for their username and password over the telephone
Searching through the trash to find documents with sensitive information

questions.text: Which of the following describes the 'Identification' step in the access control process?
options: A user providing a unique username to the system login prompt
A user proving who they are by typing a secret eight-digit PIN
A system checking the user's permissions to see which files they can open
A system recording the time and date that the user successfully logged in

questions.text: The 'Availability' portion of the CIA triad is most directly supported by which of the following?
options: Data encryption
Digital signatures
Redundant systems
Access control lists

questions.text: Which type of security control is 'Implicit Deny' when configured on a network firewall?
options: A rule that allows all traffic except what is specifically blocked
A rule that blocks all traffic except what is specifically allowed
A rule that asks for a password before allowing any web traffic
A rule that only works during specific hours of the business day

questions.text: What is the primary benefit of 'Security Awareness Training' for an organization's workforce?
options: It reduces the likelihood of successful social engineering attacks
It increases the speed at which employees can type their passwords
It allows the IT department to stop monitoring the network for threats
It provides a way for employees to fix their own hardware problems

questions.text: Which regulatory standard focuses on protecting the privacy and security of health-related information in the US?
options: PCI DSS
FERPA
HIPAA
SOX

questions.text: Which type of malware is specifically designed to hide its presence and maintain privileged access to a system without detection?
options: A standard computer virus
A self-replicating worm
A sophisticated rootkit
A credential-stealing keylogger

questions.text: What is the defining characteristic of a 'Zero-Day' vulnerability in a software application?
options: It is a vulnerability that was discovered exactly zero days ago by the vendor
It is a flaw for which no official patch or fix has been released by the developer
It is a security hole that causes the system to crash exactly at midnight
It is a weakness that only exists in newly installed operating system versions

questions.text: An attacker uses a list of common words and phrases to attempt to gain access to a user account. This is known as a:
options: Brute force attack
Dictionary attack
Rainbow table attack
Birthday attack

questions.text: Which social engineering attack involves sending highly personalized emails to a specific executive to steal corporate secrets?
options: General phishing campaign
Whaling attack
Vishing attempt
Smishing message

questions.text: A 'Logic Bomb' is a type of malicious code that is characterized by which of the following?
options: It spreads automatically across the network to all connected devices
It encrypts user files and demands payment in an untraceable currency
It triggers a destructive action when specific conditions or dates are met
It redirects internet browser traffic to a fraudulent advertising website

questions.text: What is the primary difference between a computer virus and a computer worm?
options: A virus requires a host file to spread while a worm can spread independently
A virus only affects Windows while a worm only affects Linux and Mac systems
A virus is always harmless while a worm is always designed to destroy hardware
A virus encrypts all data while a worm only steals the user's saved passwords

questions.text: Which of the following describes a 'Replay Attack' in network security?
options: An attacker captures valid data and later sends it again to gain access
An attacker crashes a server by sending the same request a million times
An attacker changes the DNS records to point to a malicious server
An attacker physically steals a backup tape and plays it on their machine

questions.text: What is 'Pharming' in the context of cyber threats?
options: Redirecting users to a fake website even if they type the correct URL
Sending fake text messages to users to steal their banking information
Using a phone call to trick someone into revealing their social security number
Infecting a computer with malware that generates cryptocurrency for the attacker

questions.text: A 'Buffer Overflow' attack is best described by which of the following?
options: Sending more data to a program than it can handle to overwrite memory
Exhausting the available power supply to a server until it shuts down
Filling up a hard drive with junk files until the operating system stops
Overwhelming a network switch with too many Ethernet cables at once

questions.text: Which of the following is a type of malware that records every character a user types on their keyboard?
options: Trojan horse
Keylogger
Adware
Spyware

questions.text: What is the primary goal of a 'SQL Injection' (SQLi) attack?
options: To shut down a web server by using up all of its CPU and RAM resources
To execute malicious database queries to steal or modify sensitive data
To bypass a physical security lock using a specialized electronic device
To infect a user's computer with a virus through a malicious email attachment

questions.text: Which type of attacker is motivated by political or social causes rather than financial gain?
options: Script Kiddie
Hacktivist
Insider Threat
State-Sponsored Actor

questions.text: What is 'Tailgating' in the context of physical security threats?
options: Driving a vehicle too closely to a delivery truck to see its contents
Following an authorized person into a secure area without their knowledge
Using a wireless antenna to capture data from a remote office building
Installing a secret hardware device on the back of a user's workstation

questions.text: Which type of vulnerability is caused by a programmer forgetting to check the size of input data?
options: Cross-Site Scripting
Buffer Overflow
SQL Injection
Broken Authentication

questions.text: A 'Trojan Horse' is characterized by which of the following behaviors?
options: It appears to be a useful program but contains hidden malicious code
It spreads itself automatically to every contact in a user's email list
It locks the computer screen and demands a payment to unlock it
It deletes itself as soon as the antivirus software starts a full scan

questions.text: What is 'Vishing'?
options: A phishing attack that is conducted over a telephone or voice call
A phishing attack that uses malicious video files to infect a computer
A phishing attack that specifically targets high-level corporate executives
A phishing attack that uses text messages sent to a user's mobile phone

questions.text: Which term describes a network of computers infected with malware and controlled by a single attacker?
options: Server Farm
Botnet
Intranet
Mesh Network

questions.text: An 'Insider Threat' is most dangerous because the individual already has:
options: A higher level of education than most external hackers
Authorized access to the organization's systems and data
The ability to use sophisticated hacking tools from the internet
Physical access to the CEO's personal home computer system

questions.text: What is 'Bluejacking' in the context of wireless threats?
options: Stealing files from a mobile device using a Bluetooth connection
Sending unsolicited messages to a mobile device via Bluetooth
Eavesdropping on a phone call made over a Bluetooth headset
Cracking the encryption of a secure Bluetooth keyboard or mouse

questions.text: Which type of threat actor is characterized by having very low technical skill and using pre-made tools?
options: Advanced Persistent Threat
Script Kiddie
Cyber Terrorist
Competitor

questions.text: What is 'Spear Phishing'?
options: A phishing attack that is sent to millions of people at once
A targeted phishing attack directed at a specific person or group
A phishing attack that uses a spear-like device to steal hardware
A phishing attack that only works on computers used for fishing

questions.text: Which attack involves an adversary sitting between two communicating parties to intercept their data?
options: Denial of Service
Man-in-the-Middle
Brute Force
Side-Channel

questions.text: A 'Rootkit' is primarily used by attackers to achieve which of the following?
options: To display as many advertisements as possible to the computer user
To gain and maintain administrative-level access while remaining hidden
To speed up the internet connection for the attacker's own use
To encrypt all of the files on the hard drive for a ransom payment

questions.text: Which of the following is a symptom of a 'DDoS' attack on a web server?
options: The server hardware physically melts from the high traffic load
The website becomes extremely slow or completely unavailable to users
The background color of the website changes to a bright red color
All of the user's saved passwords are deleted from the server database

questions.text: What is 'Adware'?
options: Malware that is designed to display unwanted advertisements on a system
Software that is used to block all advertisements on a web browser
A type of virus that specifically targets advertising companies' servers
A program that helps users create professional advertisements for free

questions.text: What is 'Typosquatting'?
options: Registering domain names that are common misspellings of popular sites
Using a computer for a very long time until the user gets tired
Hacking into a computer while the authorized user is away from the desk
Changing the keyboard layout of a computer to confuse the user

questions.text: An attacker uses 'Social Engineering' to gain access to a network by primarily exploiting:
options: Weaknesses in the firewall configuration settings
Human psychology and the natural tendency to trust
Bugs in the operating system's kernel source code
Lack of physical locks on the server room cabinets

questions.text: Which type of attack involves trying every possible combination of characters to find a password?
options: Dictionary Attack
Brute Force Attack
Rainbow Table Attack
Birthday Attack

questions.text: What is a 'Zombie' in the context of cybersecurity?
options: A computer that has been infected and is part of a botnet
An IT worker who has worked too many hours without a break
A virus that keeps coming back after it has been deleted
A deleted file that is still visible in the computer's memory

questions.text: Which of the following describes 'Cross-Site Scripting' (XSS)?
options: Injecting malicious scripts into a web page viewed by other users
Sending thousands of emails to a single user to crash their inbox
Using a specialized tool to crack a wireless network's password
Stealing a user's physical security token from their office desk

questions.text: Which architectural concept involves placing a web server in a zone that is accessible from the internet but isolated from the internal LAN?
options: Virtual Private Network
Demilitarized Zone
Intranet Segment
Extranet Gateway

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of 'Defense in Depth' in a modern enterprise security architecture?
options: To ensure that all data is backed up in at least three different geographical locations
To use multiple layers of security controls so that no single point of failure exists
To encrypt all internal communications with the highest available bit-rate levels
To prevent any external traffic from reaching the internal corporate workstations

questions.text: In a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), which key is used by the sender to encrypt a message intended for a specific recipient?
options: The sender's private key
The sender's public key
The recipient's private key
The recipient's public key

questions.text: Which hashing algorithm is currently considered insecure for cryptographic use due to its susceptibility to collision attacks?
options: SHA-256 algorithm
SHA-512 algorithm
MD5 message digest
AES-256 encryption

questions.text: The 'Salt' added to a password before hashing is primarily used to prevent which of the following?
options: The use of weak or common passwords by employees
The effectiveness of precomputed rainbow table attacks
The ability of an attacker to sniff passwords on the wire
The accidental deletion of the password database file

questions.text: In 'Asymmetric Encryption', if Alice wants to send a secure message to Bob, which key does she use?
options: Alice's private key
Alice's public key
Bob's private key
Bob's public key

questions.text: Which type of encryption uses the same key for both the encryption and decryption processes?
options: Asymmetric Encryption
Symmetric Encryption
Hashing Algorithm
Steganography

questions.text: What is the primary goal of 'Steganography' in the context of information security?
options: To encrypt data so that it cannot be understood without a secret key
To hide the existence of a message within another non-secret file
To compress data so that it takes up very little space on a hard drive
To verify the identity of a sender using a digital certificate or ID

questions.text: Which of the following is a common 'Block Cipher' algorithm used for modern data encryption?
options: RC4 algorithm
AES algorithm
MD5 algorithm
SHA-1 algorithm

questions.text: What is the function of 'Perfect Forward Secrecy' (PFS) in secure communications?
options: Ensuring that a compromised long-term key does not compromise past session keys
Ensuring that every user has a unique password that never expires or changes
Ensuring that all data is encrypted twice using two different sets of keys
Ensuring that the encryption process happens instantly without any lag or delay

questions.text: Which architectural model uses the concept of 'Subjects', 'Objects', and 'Access Modes' to define security?
options: The OSI Reference Model
The Bell-LaPadula Model
The TCP/IP Network Model
The Software Life Cycle

questions.text: A 'Digital Signature' provides which of the following three security properties?
options: Confidentiality, Speed, and Reliability
Integrity, Authentication, and Non-repudiation
Availability, Scalability, and Redundancy
Privacy, Anonymity, and Data Masking

questions.text: Which of the following is a key characteristic of the 'Biba' security model?
options: It is primarily focused on maintaining the confidentiality of data
It is primarily focused on maintaining the integrity of data
It is primarily focused on the availability of network services
It is primarily focused on the physical security of server rooms

questions.text: In cryptography, what is 'Key Stretching' used for?
options: To make a short or weak password more resistant to brute-force attacks
To physically pull on a copper wire to increase the speed of data travel
To share a single private key among many different users in a company
To increase the size of an encrypted file so it is harder for an attacker to find

questions.text: Which of the following describes 'Elliptic Curve Cryptography' (ECC)?
options: A method of encryption that uses circular logic to confuse potential hackers
A type of public-key cryptography that provides high security with smaller keys
A hardware-based encryption system that only works with curved computer monitors
A deprecated hashing algorithm that was replaced by SHA-256 ten years ago

questions.text: What is a 'Trusted Platform Module' (TPM)?
options: A software program that monitors the activity of all users on a network
A dedicated hardware chip on a computer that stores cryptographic keys
A secure website where employees can download authorized software updates
A physical room where all of the company's most important servers are kept

questions.text: The 'Secure Boot' feature in a computer's UEFI is designed to prevent:
options: The user from installing a different operating system than the one provided
The loading of unauthorized or malicious operating systems during startup
The computer from turning on if it has been physically moved from its desk
The use of any USB devices that have not been registered with the IT staff

questions.text: What is 'Obfuscation' in the context of software development and security?
options: The process of making code difficult for humans to read and understand
The process of deleting all of the source code after a program is compiled
The process of making a program run as fast as possible on older hardware
The process of translating a program into multiple different world languages

questions.text: Which of the following encryption modes is considered the most secure for modern use?
options: Electronic Code Book (ECB)
Cipher Block Chaining (CBC)
Galois/Counter Mode (GCM)
Output Feedback (OFB)

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of a 'Digital Certificate'?
options: To encrypt all of the files on a user's local hard drive
To bind a public key to a specific individual or entity
To allow a user to log in to their computer without a password
To prove that a user has completed their security awareness training

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of 'Data at Rest'?
options: Files that are being sent from a workstation to a central server
Information that is currently being displayed on a user's monitor
Data stored on a hard drive or an offline backup storage tape
Packets that are traveling through a wireless router to the internet

questions.text: What is 'Full Disk Encryption' (FDE)?
options: Encrypting only the most sensitive files on a computer's hard drive
Encrypting every single bit of data on a storage drive for security
Using a special software to make the hard drive spin faster than normal
Deleting all data on a hard drive so that it can be safely thrown away

questions.text: Which security principle suggests that systems should be secure by default without any user action?
options: Security through Obscurity
Secure by Design
Open Design Principle
Economy of Mechanism

questions.text: What is the 'Kernel' of an operating system?
options: The graphical user interface that the user interacts with most often
The core part of the OS that manages system resources and hardware
The collection of all the installed applications on the computer system
The physical case that protects the CPU and other internal components

questions.text: In the context of security design, what is a 'Fail-Safe' mechanism?
options: A system that shuts down completely if a security breach is detected
A system that remains secure even if one of its components fails
A system that allows all traffic if the security software stops working
A system that automatically backups data to the cloud every five minutes

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'Hardware Security Module' (HSM) used for?
options: To increase the processing power of a server for complex math problems
To securely manage, process, and store cryptographic keys and operations
To block physical access to a server room using an electronic keycard
To monitor the temperature of the data center to prevent fire hazards

questions.text: What is 'Sandboxing' in computer security?
options: Running an untrusted program in an isolated and restricted environment
Physically placing a server in a container filled with dry desert sand
A method of cleaning a computer's keyboard using compressed air tools
Creating a fake website to trick hackers into revealing their location

questions.text: What is 'End-to-End Encryption' (E2EE)?
options: Encryption where only the sender and receiver can read the message
Encryption that only works when both users are on the same network
Encryption that is performed by the internet service provider automatically
Encryption that only protects the data while it is stored on the server

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary weakness of 'Symmetric Encryption'?
options: It is much slower than asymmetric encryption for large amounts of data
The challenge of securely distributing the secret key to both parties
It uses too much electricity and causes mobile devices to lose battery
It is no longer supported by any modern web browsers or operating systems

questions.text: What is 'Quantum Cryptography' primarily concerned with?
options: Using the principles of quantum mechanics to secure communications
Increasing the speed of standard encryption using quantum computers
Decrypting old messages that were encrypted using legacy algorithms
A new way of storing passwords that uses liquid nitrogen for cooling

questions.text: Which network protocol operates at Layer 3 of the OSI model and is responsible for logical addressing and routing?
options: Ethernet protocol
Internet Protocol
Transmission Control Protocol
Hypertext Transfer Protocol

questions.text: A 'Stateful Inspection' firewall differs from a 'Packet Filtering' firewall because it:

questions.text: Which tool is commonly used by administrators to capture and analyze network traffic for troubleshooting or security audits?
options: A network port scanner
A protocol analyzer
A vulnerability scanner
A host-based firewall

questions.text: What is the main security risk associated with using 'Split Tunneling' on a corporate VPN connection?
options: It slows down the connection speed for all internal company applications
It allows users to bypass the corporate firewall for personal internet traffic

questions.text: Which wireless security standard uses the CCMP protocol and AES encryption to provide the highest level of security?
options: WEP protocol
WPA protocol
WPA2 protocol
TKIP protocol

questions.text: What does 'DHCP' stand for in the context of computer networking?
options: Data Handling and Control Protocol
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
Digital Hardware Connection Path
Direct Hub Communication Port

questions.text: Which of the following ports is typically used for secure web traffic (HTTPS)?
options: Port 21
Port 80
Port 443
Port 3389

questions.text: What is the primary function of a 'DNS' (Domain Name System) server?
options: To translate easy-to-read domain names into numerical IP addresses
To store the backup copies of all files found on a specific website
To prevent hackers from accessing the internal company database
To speed up the internet connection for all users in an office

questions.text: A 'VLAN' (Virtual Local Area Network) is primarily used for which of the following?
options: Connecting two different offices together over a long distance
Logically segmenting a network into smaller, isolated groups
Increasing the maximum download speed of an internet connection
Automatically updating the software on all connected workstations

questions.text: Which of the following describes 'NAT' (Network Address Translation)?

A way of making a website load faster by using a cache server
An encryption protocol used to secure wireless network connections

options: TCP is reliable and connection-oriented while UDP is fast and connectionless
TCP is used for wireless networks while UDP is used for wired connections
TCP is only used for emails while UDP is only used for web browsing traffic
TCP is insecure and outdated while UDP is the modern secure standard

questions.text: Which network device operates at Layer 2 and uses MAC addresses to forward data?
options: Hub
Router
Switch
Modem

questions.text: What is a 'MAC Address'?
options: A unique physical identifier assigned to a network interface card
The password used to log in to an Apple Macintosh computer system
A logical address used to route data across different internet sites
The security key used to encrypt a WPA2-protected wireless network

questions.text: Which port is commonly used for 'SSH' (Secure Shell) remote access?
options: Port 22
Port 23
Port 25
Port 53

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of an 'Intrusion Detection System' (IDS)?
options: To monitor network traffic and alert administrators to suspicious activity
To automatically block any user who tries to visit a social media website
To encrypt all of the data that is stored on the company's central server
To provide a high-speed wireless connection to guests in the lobby area

questions.text: Which protocol is used to send email messages between different mail servers?
options: POP3
IMAP
SMTP
HTTP

questions.text: What is 'Packet Sniffing'?

A way of cleaning the internal components of a network router or switch
Using a computer's microphone to listen to the sounds of the data center
A software feature that automatically deletes any infected email attachments

questions.text: Which of the following is an IPv6 address?
options: http://www.fbla.org

questions.text: What is the 'OSI Model'?
options: A seven-layer framework used to understand how networks communicate
A type of firewall that only works with open-source operating systems
A security policy that requires all employees to use complex passwords
A program used to create professional diagrams of network connections

questions.text: What is a 'Proxy Server' used for in a corporate network?
options: To act as an intermediary between an internal user and the internet
To provide a backup power source for the servers during a blackout
To store the user's personal files so they can be accessed from home

questions.text: Which of the following is the most secure way to manage a remote server?
options: Using Telnet on port 23
Using SSH on port 22
Using FTP on port 21
Using HTTP on port 80

questions.text: What is 'Wardriving'?

A type of racing game where players must hack into other cars' computers
Using a computer to control a self-driving car without the owner's consent
An military exercise used to test the security of a government's data center

questions.text: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for error-free delivery of data?
options: Physical Layer
Data Link Layer
Transport Layer
Session Layer

questions.text: What is 'IP Spoofing'?

Using a fake name when registering a new domain name for a website
Answering a phone call and pretending to be a representative from an ISP
Creating a fake wireless access point to steal users' login information

questions.text: Which protocol is used to automatically assign IP addresses to devices on a network?
options: DNS
DHCP
SNMP
ICMP

questions.text: What is a 'Honey Pot' in network security?

A server that stores all of the company's most important and secret files
A special software that makes the internet connection run much faster
A device that cleans the dust out of a computer's internal components

questions.text: Which of the following describes a 'Load Balancer'?

A program that checks the weight of all hardware in the server room
A security rule that limits the amount of data a user can download
A physical scale used to weigh boxes of new computer equipment

questions.text: What is 'Port Scanning'?
options: Probing a server to find which network ports are open and listening
Using a physical scanner to digitize paper documents and photos
